textBeforeTable: Shares outstanding for tech companies At the root of the problem for Facebook common stockholders is the massive share count. The company has about twice the number of shares outstanding as either Apple Inc. AAPL, -0.50%  or International Business Machines Corp. IBM, -0.08% even though those companies went public decades ago. Massively diluted stock Each time insiders sell, or when Facebook issues new shares to pay for all or part of an acquisition (as it did when buying Instagram), the company’s compensation bill goes up. Together these compensation charges and related taxes cost Facebook approximately 20 cents a share in the third quarter, net of a small, related tax benefit. The company reported that operating income fell 9% to $377 million in the quarter, hurt by surging expenses that included $179 million in stock-compensation costs. Further down the income statement, a $431 million quarterly tax charge for stock compensation swung Facebook to a loss of 2 cents a share, compared with a profit of 10 cents a year earlier. The amount of equity Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg either kept for himself and employees or sold to pre-IPO investors — such as Goldman Sachs, Russia’s DST and several venture-capital firms — have diluted significantly the stakes available to retail investors in the public markets. On top of that, the company’s IPO was enormous, adding to its share count. Now whenever insiders and employees sell restricted stock units, Facebook faces additional expenses and a portion of the related taxes owed on the sales. Close to another 800 million Facebook shares will become available for sale this week.
